lines.text: Do you think your wife would mind if I smoked my pipe?
Of course not. What's all right with me is okay with her.
I know, but a lot of dames are particular.
Well yes, but... What do you mean calling my wife a dame?
[repeated line]
There's going to be a fight.

[running into the apartment from the hallway]
It's my wife! You've got to hide!
Oh, I can explain.
Not in my pajamas you can't explain; you don't *know* my wife!
You remember how dumb I used to be?
Yeah?
Well, I'm better now.
If you want me to go, I'll stay as long as you like.
But, Dear, I haven't seen Stan in 20 years.
I couldn't see him in a hundred years.
How long did you say it would take us to get up there?
Oh, just a jiffy.
How far is a jiffy?
About three shakes of a dead lamb's tail.
I didn't think it was so far.

[Ollie's house key, attached to his pants, is stuck in the lock, so to free Ollie, he had to remove his pants; Stan easily removes the key from the lock]
Why didn't you tell me you had the key out of the lock?
Well, you didn't ask me.
"You didn't ask me".
Gee, that's pretty underwear.
Don't get personal.
Ha ha ha! Come see my grandfather. My grandfather left. He said, "Hello, sugar!"

[Responding after Hardy asks if there's anything in the newspaper]
Here's a story about a fella who spent twenty years in the trenches and didn't know the war was over.

[laughing]
Really?
Yeah; here's his picture
[shows Hardy the paper]

[Looking at a photo of the grinning soldier]
I can't imagine anybody being that dumb.

[Realizes the grinning soldier is Stan; does a massive take and grabs the paper back from Morton; looks directly into the camera]
Oh, yes I can.
No, you see, everybody thought I was dead. Didn't they?
Um, hmm.
How did you find out you weren't?

[Leers at Stan and Ollie]
While the Cat's away the Rats will play huh? Listen, I know where we can find a couple of beautiful blondes!
But, Toots, Stan is different.
I'll say he's different!
What's a knick-knack?
Oh a knick-knack is a thing that sits on top of a whatnot.

[adorably]
And make that hour short.

[coming back from store]
So you were only going to be gone an hour!

[to 901 guy]
There's going to be a fight.

[to bypassers]
There's going to be a fight.

[to guy going into apartment]
Hey, there's going to be a fight.

[to desk guy]
You better call an ambulance. It's going to be terrible. There's going to be a fight.
Why didn't you tell me you had two legs?
Well, you didn't ask me... I've always had 'em...

[sarcastically]
You're better now...
I know where there's a whole bunch of blondes!
I don't bring 'em back alive; I shoot 'em. I come back alive.
